item.title: Stochastic Process
item.description: def. Time Series is a stochastic process indexed by discrete (integer) time points. See discussion: Is a time series the same as a stochastic process? - Cross Validated def.

item.title: Stochastic Calculus
item.description: def. Ito Integral. Let the following: Brownian Motion B={Bs​∣s≥0}, an Ito process X={Xs​∣s≥0} 0=t1​<t2​<⋯<tn​=t and thus ti​=nt​i Then the Ito integral Yt​ of X(t) with respect to B(t) is defined as such: Y(t)=∫0t​X(s)dB(s):=n→∞lim​i=0∑n​X(ti−1​)[Bti​​−Bti−1​​] Visualization.

item.title: Sequence Summation
item.description: Geometric Series: a,ar,ar2,…,arn Sn​=a⋅1−r1−rn​ If it converges, the infinite sum: S∞​=1−ra​ Arithmetic Sequence: a,a+d,a+2d,…a+nd Sn​=2n​⋅(2a+(n−1)d) Other Summations: See Convergence tests - Wikiwand Properties of Summations § (i=0∑n​ai​)2=i=0∑n​ai2​+i=j∑n​ai​aj​.

item.title: CS 535 Algorithmic Game Theory
item.description: Game Theory Equilibria in Game Theory Potential Games Traffic Routing No-Regret Dynamics Auction Theory Revenue-Maximizing Auctions Optimal Stopping Problem .

item.title: Auction Theory
item.description: def. Sealed Bid Auction. An auction is a game where there are a certain number of buyers, buyers each have their value, vi​ and bid, bi​. The auction process takes in the bids of all buyers b, and outputs the allocation x(b) and price p​(b).

item.title: Ordinary Least Squares Regression
item.description: Motivation. Let’s say that there is a relationship between GDP per capita and life expectancy. Maybe god has declared a perfect formula describing this relationship: \text{GDP Per Capita}=200\cdot \text{Life Expectancy}+1000+\text{Noise} $$While we humans may never truly know the parameters of the formula, $200$ and $1000$, we can still make a good guess about it.

item.title: Proof Techniques
item.description: Algebraic You can split summations (even infinite ones) ∏i​eXi​=e∑i​Xi​ Equivalently, ln(∏i​Xi​)=∑i​(lnXi​) Pushing log thru product makes it a sum Telescoping sums and products Probability Tower property E(X)=E(E(X∣F)) Linearity of expectation.

item.title: Student's t-test
item.description: def. let X1​,…,Xn​∼iidN(μ,σ2). We are comparing two hypothesis: H0​:μ≤μ0​ H1​:μ>μ0​ Then, let T=σ^/n​Xˉn​−μ0​​ where σ^=n−1E[(Xˉn​−Xi​)]​ is the besset-corrected variance estimator.
